hazard_discussion:
The clear weather we've seen for the past two weeks is expected to start moving out today, but impacts are looking to be minimal. We may see a slight increase in easterly winds but it is unlikely they will get strong enough to move enough snow to elevate the avalanche danger. It's been 16 days since we measured any precipitation and conditions are generally stable. However, there is a very small chance you may encounter isolated pockets of unstable snow in steep terrain. Even though the danger is low, it is still important to maintain safe travel protocol like traveling one at a time in steep terrain and watching partners from safe spots outside of avalanche runout zones. 

Glide Avalanches: We've seen a lot of glide cracks reappear over the past two weeks, and have recorded a few glide avalanches releasing. These are large and unpredictable, so the only way to manage the problem is to avoid traveling below open glide cracks.

Cornices are another constant hazard. They can release naturally, or they can fail under the weight of a person. Your best bet is to avoid spending time below large cornices and to give them plenty of space if you are traveling along ridgelines.

author: John Sykes
bottom_line:
Our main concerns are large glide avalanches, wet avalanches, and cornice falls, which are a normal part of the transition to a spring snowpack. These tend to be most concerning on steep sunny slopes later in the day as the surface crust melts. These avalanches have the potential to step down to a deeper buried weak layer 4 to 6' deep and cause a much larger avalanche. On northern aspects at upper elevations, where dry snow still exists, smaller wind slab avalanches could also be a concern.

A weak layer of surface hoar buried 4 to 6’ deep is still a concern and fresh wind slabs may be forming in upper elevations. Choosing slopes that do not have terrain traps on them is a safer option if you get into avalanche terrain.

If it feels warm then seeking shady slopes will be the safest option. Look out for small slab avalanches from new snow that could warm up and slide easily on a crust as well as small wind slabs that may have fallen on a crust in upper elevations.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line:
Today we expect a break between storms. Avalanche danger will start out MODERATE and may rise to CONSIDERABLE if the sun heats the snowpack more than anticipated. After so much recent avalanche activity due to large storms, an assessment mindset is a good approach today. Lingering wind slabs up to 3' deep should be on the stubborn side, but could be triggered by a person especially in steep upper elevation terrain. If the sun comes out before new storm clouds move in, wet avalanches will be quick to fail in steep terrain. A fresh glide avalanche released on Tincan yesterday so continue to keep an eye out for glide cracks and avoid traveling in their path.  The Valentine's Day buried surface hoar is buried so deep it is becoming unlikely a person could trigger an avalanche on this layer.

WEDNESDAY'S AVALANCHE OUTLOOK:  HIGH AVALANCHE DANGER is on the way for Wednesday. Another warm storm is expected to pick up through the day and bring 1 to 4" of water (several feet of snow above rainline) to Turnagain Pass, Girdwood, Portage, Summit Lake, and Seward by the end of the day on Wednesday. Strong easterly ridgetop winds will accompany the precipitation making natural avalanches and human-triggered avalanches very likely. This will make avalanche conditions very dangerous, and travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended for Wednesday.

bottom_line: Avalanche danger will rise to HIGH as a potent storm impacts the area, bringing up to 2" of water or 2' of snow above 2000' in the next 24 hours. author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line: Wet snow avalanches are the main concern once again. We have seen widespread wet slab, wet loose, and glide avalanche activity this week, and are expecting to see more today. author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line: The avalanche danger will start out MODERATE and rise to CONSIDERABLE as the air temperature and sun melt the snow surface. There were at least 15 new glide avalanches observed yesterday in the Turnagain Pass zone (including Girdwood), which makes this the most concerning problem today. These avalanches are very dangerous and it's best to avoid being underneath any glide crack right now. Wet loose avalanches are occurring naturally and are growing in size with each passing warm day and more dangerous wet slabs are becoming possible. As surface crusts break down, or where they don't exist, a person could also trigger a large avalanche on a layer of buried surface hoar that is 2 to 3' deep in Turnagain Pass. There is a lot of uncertainty with the timing of dangerous conditions and these problems can be avoided by choosing low angle slopes.

author: Daniel Krueger
bottom_line: The avalanche danger will transition from MODERATE to CONSIDERABLE as the sun and warm temperatures melts the snow surface which will increase the chance of triggering a large avalanche 2 to 3’ deep on a layer of buried surface hoar. It will be easier to trigger an avalanche on slopes that do not have a supportable crust. The safest option is to avoid traveling on or above steep slopes. We are in the middle of a glide cycle where many glide cracks are opening and releasing as large glide avalanches. Try to avoid spending time under glide cracks. Finally, wet loose avalanches are releasing on sunny slopes and wind slabs around a foot deep may be easy to trigger today on slopes exposed to the wind.

author: John Sykes

author: Daniel Krueger
bottom_line: There is a chance of triggering a large avalanche 2 to 3’ deep on a layer of buried surface hoar. Warm temperatures will make it likely to trigger wet loose avalanches on sunny slopes. The safest option is to move to shadier aspects in the afternoon.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line:
It has been one week since the fatal avalanche on Seattle Ridge and avalanche conditions remain dangerous despite relatively calm weather through the week. There are still chances a person could trigger a large avalanche 2' deep or more on a layer of buried surface hoar anywhere above 1,500'. The only way to completely avoid this problem is to stick to low angle slopes with nothing steep above. Warm temperatures this week caused an increase in glide avalanches and wet loose avalanches. Debris from these slides is running below treeline in places like Girdwood and Seward. Be on the lookout for glide cracks and avoid spending time under them as they seem especially primed for release and can run all the way to flat ground at sea level.

It is back to calm and sunny today for one more day before the pattern shifts. Elevated ridgetop easterly winds on Monday created blowing snow and wind slabs in Turnagain Pass and Summit Lake. These are 2 days old by now and should be stabilizing, but keep an eye out for stiff snow over softer snow especially in the upper elevations. Stubborn wind slabs aren't as likely to give a warning sign like a shooting crack so watch for hazards in the runout below in case an unlikely avalanche occurs. The sun is having an effect on the snow in several ways. First, with warm temperatures, sun, and calm wind we could see natural loose avalanches especially near rocks on steep south facing slopes. Second, cornice falls could occur naturally or be triggered by a human or machine especially in the heat of the afternoon. Last, the sun has been heating up the south facing slopes and a thin sun crust is present in many areas. This last effect isn't much of a problem right now, but may start to affect the riding conditions and become a layer for an avalanche to slide on with a new load of snow especially since it has surface hoar sitting on top of it in many places. 

Another fresh glide avalanche was observed yesterday above Johnson Lake, which is in the Bench Peak area on the north border of the Summit Lake zone. We aren't seeing a lot of these glide cracks releasing, but with their unpredictable nature it's still a good idea to avoid spending any time underneath if possible.

hazard_discussion:
We're expecting another day of quiet weather today before we see a slight increase in winds starting tonight. With no major weather on the way and no avalanche activity in the past eight days, all signs are pointing to generally stable conditions. It is very unlikely a person will trigger an avalanche today, but we can never rule out that possibility entirely. If you are taking advantage of this spell of good weather and stable conditions to get into steep terrain, there are a few things you can keep in mind to improve your odds of recovering from an unlikely avalanche encounter today:

  • Only expose one person at a time in steep terrain, and keep an eye on partners from safe locations outside of runout zones. Think about what it actually means to be in a safe spot; it often means staying farther away from overhead terrain than one would expect.
  • Play the what-if game before getting into steep terrain. Do you have an escape route off the slope if you are the unlucky one to trigger a small avalanche? If you are watching your partner, are you close enough to get to them in a reasonable amount of time if they need help?
  • Be aware of overhead hazards like cornices  and glide cracks. Both are present across our advisory area, and both can release unexpectedly. If you're traveling along ridgelines, give cornices plenty of room since they often break further back than we'd expect.

We've had a great stretch of weather and stability, but don't let yourself get lulled into complacency. Conditions may be generally stable across a broad area, but there is always some variability that we can't account for. Safe travel protocol can help you recover if your group is the unlucky one to find that unlikely pocket.

High pressure continues to dominate the weather pattern and generally low avalanche danger exists. As always, low danger does not mean no danger. Glide avalanches continue to release and cause very large and destructive avalanches. Try to minimize your time underneath glide cracks and use safe travel practices to expose one person at a time. Human triggered wind slab avalanches could still be possible in localized areas of steep terrain that saw recent wind loading. Keep an eye out for hollow feeling pillows of snow or shooting cracks in wind loaded areas to identify slopes that could harbor lingering wind slabs. 

Large cornices exist along many ridgelines which could be a hazard if you are traveling along a ridgeline or directly underneath. Try to stay a little farther back from the ridgeline than seems necessary to avoid a surprise cornice collapse and be aware that cornice crevasses can form along ridgelines as the cornice starts to peel away from the mountain side. 

Both dry and wet loose avalanches are also possible today. Dry loose avalanches could occur on any steep slope with soft snow on the surface and we recommend having a plan to deal with sluff if you are traveling in steep terrain. Wet loose avalanches will be limited to steep south facing terrain and could form sun crusts or release very small natural avalanches.

These will likely be small but may have higher consequences in steep rocky terrain. Watch out for loose “sluff” avalanches and the potential for glide avalanches.

The Crow Creek area has a thinner snowpack than the rest of Turnagain Pass and additional caution is warranted there. Here are some more details on the hazards and things to think about while we take advantage of this weather window. 

Recent Avalanches: We've gotten reports the last few days of small wet loose avalanches or "sluffs" being triggered naturally by the sun and warm temperatures heating the rocks on south facing slopes. One larger sluff was observed as it was occurring in the 20 Mile drainage yesterday (video below). These are the first avalanches we are aware of since the human triggered wind slab in Lynx Creek on Friday. John and Andrew investigated the very large avalanche that occurred in Ragged Bowl on January 25. Check out that video below and a report will be available soon.

Lingering Wind Slabs: We don't expect a person could trigger a wind slab today, but a stubborn one could surprise us. Watch for stiffer snow over softer snow under a ridgeline or in a cross loaded gully (see example below on Pete's North). The strong winds last week came from many directions so these could be found on any aspect. 

Cornices: Temperatures remained warm overnight in the upper elevations. This, combined with the forecast sun today, will make higher chances for a natural or human triggered cornice fall. These are unlikley to trigger an avalanche below, but there is evidence of recent cornice fall in this zone and the chunks are big enough to do some damage if they hit us from above. 

Sun effect: Many small "sluffs" were observed in Bertha Creek yesterday on the south facing slopes. There are good chances this will happen again today and there may be a sun crust on these slopes as well. There is plenty of winter left, but it is time to add the sun to the list of how the weather changes the snowpack.

Glide avalanches: New glide cracks are being noticed daily in Turnagain Pass and Summit Lake. It seems they were encouraged to wake up by the combination of the last big storm followed by a cold spell. The only one to release recently, that we know of, was sometime last week on the south end of Seattle Ridge. Two days ago, a group was surprised to find themselves climbing up over a glide crack that they hadn't been able to see due to the steep slope. Avoid spending time under them if you can, the next one could release at any time.

Safe Travel: Sticking with safe systems, even during periods of low danger, will reduce our chances of getting into trouble if we get surprised by something today. This includes making a travel plan with multiple options depending on what we find out there, checking our transceivers, airbags, communications, and other rescue gear before heading up, and traveling one at a time in avalanche terrain.

hazard_discussion:
What a brilliant weekend with sunshine and warm temperatures in the upper elevations. Parking lots at Turnagain Pass were at full capacity and no reports of avalanches. Today, and even tomorrow, should be equally nice. As folks continue to get into the bigger and steeper terrain, there are several things to be sure and consider. First, the snowpack in the Crow Creek area of Girdwood and the Johnson Pass/Silvertip area between Turnagain Pass and Summit Lake are suspect for harboring buried weak layers. These areas are on the periphery of the forecast zone and warrant extra caution and snowpack assessment. Second, anytime snow is on the mountains there is always some degree of avalanche hazard. Here is rundown:

Lingering Wind Slabs: Various wind slabs are scattered about from the strong northwest outflow winds last week. As always, keep a lookout for where winds have drifted snow and loading slopes. Signs of cracking in the snow around you and stiffer snow over softer snow are clues you've found a wind slab. These can be highly consequential in steep rocky terrain.

Cornices: As anyone that has been out in the mountains after January’s stormy weather knows, the cornices are big. We can’t stress enough how important it is to give these an extra wide berth. They could be easier to trigger as warm temperatures are now being seen above 2,000’ and sunshine will add to this warmth during the midday hours. They are notorious for breaking back further than expected and it’s also a good idea to limit time under them.

Sluffing in the heat of the day: It's that time of year the sun is starting to heat up the rocky terrain facing south. With such warm ambient temperatures in the Alpine currently, the sun can tip the balance in the afternoon. One group noted sun triggered sluffs in Tincan's Library yesterday.

Glide avalanches: Glide cracks are continuing to ooze open throughout the forecast areas. We are only aware of one that has released so far (south end of Seattle Ridge), but more cracks are appearing every day. These avalanches are very large and unpredictable. The best way to manage this problem is to avoid spending time under open glide cracks.

Safe Travel: As always, pay attention to the conditions in the area where you are traveling, and adjust objectives if you notice any surprising signs like shooting cracks or collapsing. You can minimize the consequences of finding an unlucky pocket of unstable snow by sticking with safe travel protocols. This includes traveling one at a time in steep terrain, watching partners from safe locations, and carrying appropriate rescue gear so you can recover if things go wrong.

Recent Avalanches: There were no avalanches reported over the weekend. The last known avalanches were on Friday when a skier triggered a wind slab in steep terrain in the Lynx Creek drainage and a snowmachiner triggered a small slab on Seattle Ridge.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line:
It is unlikely - not impossible - that a person will trigger an avalanche today. You may still find isolated pockets of reactive snow in some steep wind-loaded terrain, but those chances are slim as another quiet day of weather is on the way. Even though conditions are generally stable, it is still important to follow safe travel protocols like traveling one at a time in steep terrain and watching partners from safe areas outside of runout zones.

Recent Avalanches: On Friday a skier triggered an avalanche on a steep, wind-loaded terrain feature in the Lynx Creek drainage. The skier was caught and carried, sustained serious injuries and was evacuated by the Air National Guard. We have posted a full report on the incident and the response here. Thank you to the parties involved for sharing the information and photos. We're wishing the injured skier a quick recovery.

After several days of quiet weather and no major layers of concern in the Turnagain Pass zone, it is unlikely that a person will trigger an avalanche today. That is a broad statement for a large area, so be careful how you use that information. A few things to keep in mind:

  • There is always a small chance of finding pockets of unstable snow, especially in steep alpine terrain. This was the case with the recent avalanche incident on Friday, and although chances of finding something similar today are small, they are never zero.
  • The snowpack in the Crow Creek area on the northwest corner of the Turnagain forecast zone may be more similar to the Summit Lake snowpack than the rest of the Turnagain Pass zone. If you travel in that area, it will be important to be a little more careful with snowpack assessment and terrain management.
  • The snowpack from Johnson Pass to Silvertip Creek is a transitional zone between the generally stable Turnagain Pass snowpack and the potentially problematic Summit Lake setup. Similarly to Crow Creek, this area warrants a little more caution than the core of the Turnagain Pass zone. 

Avalanche accidents happen even when the danger is low. As always, pay attention to the conditions in the area where you are traveling, and adjust objectives if you notice any surprising signs like shooting cracks or collapsing. You can minimize the consequences of finding an unlucky pocket of unstable snow by sticking with safe travel protocols. This includes traveling one at a time in steep terrain, watching partners from safe locations, and carrying appropriate rescue gear so you can recover if things go wrong.

Cornices: There are many large cornices that will begin to heat up during the temperature inversion that is settling in this week. These often catch people by surprise, breaking back much further from the edge than we'd expect. Keep that in mind if you are traveling along ridgelines, and be sure to limit spending time under them since they can release naturally.

Glide avalanches: Glide cracks continue to pop open throughout our forecast areas. We are only aware of one that has released so far, but more are appearing every day. These avalanches are very large and unpredictable. The best way to manage this problem is to avoid spending time under open glide cracks.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line:
The main concern for Turnagain Pass is triggering an avalanche 1 to 3 feet deep where the wind has blown snow into stiffer slabs, especially at upper elevations. These are slowly becoming more stubborn and less likely to trigger, but with two human-triggered avalanches yesterday these are still an issue to pay attention to. Look for better stability and surface conditions in terrain that has remained sheltered from recent winds, still holding soft snow on the surface.

author: Graham Predeger
bottom_line:
With another potent storm on the doorstep this weekend, the avalanche danger will be on the rise throughout the day and overnight hours tonight.  Through the Turnagain Pass area there is 1-2' of soft snow available for transport that may form fresh wind slabs 1-3' deep as winds are forecasted to increase from the SSE.  Additionally, we may see rain on snow as high as 1,800' late in the day.  If that verifies, wet loose avalanches could be a concern in steep terrain, and may pull out a slab avalanche 1-3' down. 

Today will be a good day to ensure you are out of the field before the weather makes a turn for the worse.

__________________________________________

This weekend's storm is expected to have widespread impacts in Southcentral Alaska, and it is looking like Hatcher Pass is right in the crosshairs. Visit hpavalanche.org for more information.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line: The weather has quieted down significantly, but southwest ridgetop winds are forecast today. If this occurs, fresh wind slabs up to 1' deep that are sensitive to the weight of a person will build in the upper elevations. There's a chance a person or machine could trigger an older, deeper (up to 3') and more stubborn wind slab above 1,000' from the strong winds that occurred Tuesday evening.  Wind slabs can be found below ridgelines and on the edges of cross loaded gullies. Softer snow can be found in areas protected from Tuesday's strong winds.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line:
A storm is moving out today that brought strong easterly ridgetop winds and heavy snowfall above 1,000' last night. While we might not see natural avalanches today, but it could be easy for a person to trigger a storm slab (~1' deep) or wind slab avalanche (~2 to 3' deep) in the new and windblown snow. A cautious approach to avalanche terrain today that includes testing the snow on small inconsequential slopes is a good way to see how this new snow is stabilizing. It is becoming more unlikely that a person would be able to trigger a very large avalanche on a weak layer buried 4 to 6' deep. This is more likely to occur in the southern part of Turnagain Pass where the snowpack is thinner.

author: Daniel Krueger
bottom_line: The avalanche danger will increase to HIGH today as strong east winds are forecast to gust 70+ mph. Wind slabs 2 to 4’ deep will be easy for a human to trigger above 2,500’ on wind loaded slopes. There is also an unlikely chance a human could trigger a large avalanche 4 to 6’ deep on a buried layer of weak snow. Traveling in avalanche terrain is not recommended on slopes that are exposed to the wind.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line: The storm that brought 1-1.5' of snow to the area yesterday has exited, but conditions may still be reactive today. Treat the new snow as guilty until proven innocent today, and expect to find the most dangerous conditions on slopes where winds have blown the snow into thicker slabs up to 2 or 3' deep. There is a much smaller chance that you may be able to trigger a much larger avalanche on weak snow buried 4 to 6' deep. These problems will take careful snowpack evaluation, and it may be difficult to identify which terrain is holding the weakest snow. If in doubt, you can avoid the problem entirely by sticking to lower-angle terrain.

author: Wendy Wagner
bottom_line:
There is a HIGH avalanche danger in the Girdwood and Turnagain Pass areas due to heavy snowfall and strong winds. Natural avalanches are likely and human triggered avalanches are very likely during and just after the storm. Avalanches could be large enough to send debris into valley bottoms. Travel in avalanche terrain is NOT recommended.

The National Weather Service has issued a Winter Weather Advisory for Turnagain Pass due to 12 to 20 inches of snow that could accumulate on the road by later today.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line:

Dangerous conditions will develop, with natural and human-triggered avalanches likely where strong easterly winds are loading slopes above 1000'. These wind slab avalanches will be around 1' deep and will be becoming larger and more sensitive through the day. Avalanche danger will spike tonight, and is expected to reach HIGH by sunrise tomorrow.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line:
Fresh wind slabs are forming in the upper elevations where strong easterly winds and a few inches of snow arrived overnight. These wind slabs should only be up to 1' deep, but have the potential to trigger an avalanche 4 to 6' deep or more on a weak layer buried below the snow from the last two storms. Safer terrain and softer snow can be found in places that are protected from the wind.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line: The weather is clearing but the avalanche conditions remain dangerous, especially at higher elevations. It will be easy to trigger an avalanche where winds have recently blown snow into steep terrain. These will likely be 1 to 2 feet deep on their own, but they have the potential to trigger a massive avalanche failing 4 to 6' deep or deeper on weak snow buried in the middle of the snowpack. Look for safer conditions and better riding in terrain that has been protected from the wind, and consider avoiding steep alpine terrain entirely while the snowpack has more time to settle.

author: Wendy Wagner
bottom_line:
Human triggered avalanches are likely as yesterday's powerful storm exits. Triggering a large slab avalanche, up to several feet deep and hundreds of feet wide, on any aspect above 1,000' is the main concern. This is due to several feet of new storm snow that has not bonded yet to the snow underneath. Additionally, even larger avalanches could be triggered if they break in a weak layer 4 to 6' deep. 

*A conservative mindset is essential on these first days after big storms. There are a lot of unknowns but the main point is - large and deadly avalanches could be triggered by people today. It is best to let the steeper slopes adjust to this new load and stick to lower angle terrain.

A lull between storms is expected this afternoon before another very strong storm impacts the area. Avalanche danger will peak overnight tonight with the potential for very large natural avalanches.

These avalanches could be large enough to run below treeline so overhead hazard is a concern. Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended.

Look out for and avoid traveling under slopes where glide cracks could release and cornices could fall creating large avalanches above you. Dangerous avalanche conditions exist today. author: Wendy Wagner
bottom_line: Dangerous avalanche conditions exist. A powerful storm is moving through the region today raising the avalanche danger to HIGH. Heavy rain, snow, and very strong winds will cause avalanches to release naturally in many areas and debris could run down avalanche paths into snow-free zones below 1,000'. In the high elevations these avalanches could be several feet deep due to heavy snowfall. Travel in avalanche terrain is NOT recommended.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line: An approaching storm is bringing strong winds to the area, with precipitation increasing starting this afternoon. Expect avalanche danger to increase as the weather arrives. For now the biggest concern is triggering an avalanche up to a foot deep on wind loaded slopes. Conditions will quickly become more dangerous as the storm picks up right around sunset, so pay attention to changing conditions later in the day.

author: Daniel Krueger
bottom_line:
An approaching storm looks to bring increased east winds and snow throughout the day. If the winds arrive sooner than expected, small wind slabs will be the main concern at upper elevations. Otherwise, look out for older wind slabs and glide cracks releasing as avalanches. Give cornices a wide berth and watch for dry loose avalanches on steep slopes.

The avalanche danger is expected  to rise as the storm is forecast to become more intense Sunday into Monday evening.

author: John Sykes
bottom_line: Glide avalanches and lingering isolated wind slabs are the main concerns today. The snowpack is generally stable. However, there is always a possibility of finding an isolated unstable slope in steep terrain. Remember to assess the snowpack as you travel and be aware of general hazards like cornices and dry loose avalanches.
hazard_discussion:
Quiet weather and generally stable snowpack conditions are expected to continue today. Winds could pick up to 10-20 mph out of the east at upper elevations this afternoon but given the strong winds early this week, it is unlikely that there is enough snow left for transport to create widespread wind slabs. Keep an eye out for active wind loading or shooting cracks on wind loaded slopes as a sign that wind slabs are forming. If wind slabs form, they are expected to be less than 1' deep and isolated to areas with strong winds and soft snow remaining on the surface. 

General mountain hazards to look out for include cornices, glide cracks, and dry loose avalanches (sluff). Keep in mind that low danger does not mean no danger, and it is important to always assess the snowpack as you travel to identify potential hazards.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line: With a generally stable snowpack and quiet weather, it is unlikely a person will trigger a slab avalanche today. Although, an old small wind slab in steep upper elevation terrain could be an outlier. There are good chances of triggering a dry loose (sluff) avalanche especially in steep terrain. Continuing to use systems like traveling one at a time in steep terrain, and watching partners from a safe spot will help us be more prepared if a surprise avalanche happens. New glide cracks are still showing up so continue to avoid traveling under them.
hazard_discussion:
Wind Slab: An easterly wind event that began over the weekend diminished on Tuesday night. While calm weather prevails today, there are some older wind slabs in the upper elevations that are sitting on weak snow that formed before the winds arrived. There's a chance a person could trigger one of these avalanches but they could be pretty stubborn and should only be 1' deep or so. Older wind slabs may not give signs like shooting cracks or whumpfs, but they may sound or feel hollow. 

Dry Loose: Small dry loose "sluffs" were triggered yesterday by riders on the Seattle Ridge side of Turnagain Pass. We expect this to be the case today especially in steep terrain. Watch for hazards below in case you get caught up in sluff and knocked over. 

Cornice: We found an old, large cornice fall yesterday on the Seattle Ridge side of Turnagain Pass. With quiet weather, the cornice fall activity has been slowing down, and it's unlikley a cornice fall would trigger a larger slab avalanche, but falling off a ridge with a chunk of cornice might not be the best part of the day.

Glide: The glide activity has slowed, but yesterday a new crack was noticed on Seattle Ridge. We hope the slow will come to a stop, but until then, continue to avoid traveling underneath glide cracks when possible.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line:
Triggering a wind slab avalanche that could be 1 to 2' deep, which formed over weak snow in the last 2 days, is still a concern despite diminishing winds today. This problem can be found on upper elevation wind loaded slopes. Glide cracks are creeping downhill so avoid spending time underneath them when possible.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line: Today is the third day in a row of heavy snow and rain with strong easterly winds. Dangerous avalanche conditions continue with storm slab and wind slab problems in the upper elevations and wet snow problems below 2,500'. With the warm and wet weather we expect glide avalanche activity to continue. Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line: Heavy snow and rain with strong easterly winds are expected to continue today. This will make for dangerous avalanche conditions with wet snow avalanche problems below 2500', and new snow avalanche problems including storm and wind slabs at higher elevations. Continued rain on snow below 2500' may also increase glide avalanche activity. We are expecting another action-packed day with weather and avalanches, and travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended.

author: John Sykes
bottom_line: A strong storm impacting the region will rapidly increase the avalanche danger throughout the day. Travel in avalanche terrain is not recommended. Lower elevation terrain that is typically safe could be hazardous today due to avalanches running into valley bottoms.

author: John Sykes
bottom_line: Windy conditions are expected to continue today with snow above 1700'. Human triggered or natural wind slabs up to a foot deep on leeward slopes are the main concern. In isolated locations a layer of buried surface hoar underneath older wind slabs could cause larger human triggered avalanches. Glide avalanches continue to release and we recommend avoiding glide cracks.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line: Strong easterly winds are forecast today making natural wind slab avalanches possible and human triggered avalanches likely in the upper elevations. These "pillows" of windblown snow could be 1 to 2' deep and are typically found below ridgelines, on convex rolls, and in cross loaded gullies. Two new glide avalanches were noticed yesterday, which means this problem is still active. Visibility could be limited so keep your eyes out for glide cracks and avoid spending time underneath them if possible.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line: With strong east to northeast winds blowing through the day yesterday, wind slabs that could be 1 to 2' deep are the main concern today. These "pillows" of windblown snow can be found below ridgelines and in cross loaded gullies. The size of the avalanches today could take us for a ride to a place we don't want to go, so watch for hazards like rocks and cliffs that we might get pushed into if we get surprised. Glide avalanches are still a concern. It is difficult to avoid traveling underneath glide cracks in Turnagain Pass these days so we recommend a safe travel plan that includes moving quickly and one at a time.

author: Daniel Krueger
bottom_line: Wind slabs 1 to 1.5' deep will be easy to trigger above treeline today. In mid elevations these may be forming on a slick crust. Easing into steep terrain and steering clear of steep wind loaded slopes is the safest option. Glide cracks continue to release so avoid spending time under them whenever possible.

author: Wendy Wagner
bottom_line: Increasing winds in the upper elevations will likely be forming touchy wind slabs around a foot deep throughout the day. Winds could also form thin slabs over slick crusts in the mid elevations. These slabs could release naturally or be easily triggered by people on steep freshly wind loaded slopes. Glide avalanches remain an issue in many areas so continuing to steer clear of glide cracks is recommended.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line:
An increase in winds will make it easy to trigger an avalanche up to a foot deep, and may even make some natural avalanches. Expect to find increasing avalanche danger as the weather picks up today, and plan on avoiding steep wind loaded slopes. Glide avalanches also remain a major concern in the Turnagain Pass area. The best way to manage this problem is to avoiding spending time under slopes with open glide cracks.

bottom_line:
Glide avalanches are the biggest concern today in the Turnagain Pass zone. The brief break in the weather is not expected to do much to change the alarming rate of glide avalanche activity we've seen, especially this week. These avalanches are very dangerous and unpredictable. The only way to manage the problem is to avoid spending time below open glide cracks. This is becoming more and more difficult, and requires getting a good look at overhead terrain before traveling under steep slopes. If you manage to find cold snow in the alpine, there is also a chance you might be able to trigger wind slab avalanches, especially in steep gullies, below ridgelines, or on convex rolls.

author: John Sykes
bottom_line:
Stormy weather continues today with 30-40 mph winds and up to 1” of water. Natural and human triggered avalanches are likely. Wet avalanches will be found below 2500' with wind slabs above 2500'. Glide avalanches are releasing at an alarming rate and creating large and destructive avalanches. If you get out today we recommend avoiding steep slopes and being aware of runout zones from overhead avalanches that could release naturally.

Portage/Placer: Coastal areas have received almost 7" of water this week. This is a very big load on top of the existing snowpack. Natural avalanches are especially likely in these areas receiving the heaviest precipitation.

author: John Sykes
bottom_line:
Three days of continuous rain up to about 2500' are creating unstable avalanche conditions. Natural avalanches are likely in steep terrain where wet snow and glide cracks are causing avalanches large enough to bury a person. At higher elevations where snow is falling, the combination of wind and new snow will make it easy to trigger an avalanche within the new snow. We recommend a cautious approach to avalanche terrain today, including avoiding runout zones from overhead avalanche paths. 

Portage/Placer: Coastal areas have received almost 6" of total precipitation over the past few days which is a big load on top of the existing snowpack. Natural avalanches are especially likely in these areas receiving the heaviest precipitation.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line:
Wet avalanches are the main concern today below 3,000' where rain is falling on dry snow. Rollerballs are a sign that this type of problem could occur. At the highest elevations strong winds and snowfall are building drifts of dense snow that could be 2' deep or more. It will be likely for a human to trigger a wind slab where these drifts are forming. Watch for and avoid areas with blowing snow.

Glide cracks are still a concern and could release into large and dangerous avalanches. They are more difficult to see in these cloudy conditions, but look for that "brown frown" or wrinkly snow and avoid traveling underneath if possible.

Portage/Placer: This area received over 4" of water (rain) in the last 24 hours. Above rainline this is 4+ feet of new snow. Avalanche conditions are especially dangerous where this amount of precipitation has fallen.

author: Daniel Krueger
bottom_line:
Strong winds and snow will deposit fresh wind slabs 1 to 2' deep on top of buried weak snow. These will be larger and easier to trigger as east winds and snowfall increases throughout the day. The safest option is to avoid steep wind loaded slopes. 

Above freezing temperatures in mid to upper elevations could increase the chance for glide avalanche activity. Avoid this problem by staying away from glide cracks as they can release at any time.

author: Wendy Wagner
bottom_line:
Watch for fresh wind slabs that formed from the strong winds over the past 24-hours in the higher elevations. These slabs could be up to a foot deep and found just off ridgelines and in cross-loaded gullies. Otherwise, glide avalanches remain a concern as they are still releasing in highly trafficked areas. Look for and avoid being under glide cracks.

Avalanche danger is expected to rise tomorrow, Tuesday, with strong winds and rain/snowfall.

author: John Sykes
bottom_line: Winds are expected to increase today and wind transported snow could cause natural or human triggered avalanches 6-12" deep in isolated areas at higher elevations. Keep an eye out for active wind transport and shooting cracks on the snow surface to identify wind loaded areas. Glide avalanches are also still a concern and can cause large and destructive avalanches. Stay safe by avoiding spending time underneath open glide cracks.

author: Daniel Krueger
bottom_line: The most concerning avalanche activity is glide cracks releasing as avalanches above commonly skied slopes and skin tracks. The safest option is to avoid spending time under these large "brown" cracks.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line: Glide avalanches are the main concern in Turnagain Pass. There have been active glide cracks moving and releasing in popular areas for several weeks. Avoid traveling under open glide cracks whenever possible since these avalanches are very large and unpredictable.

author: Mik Dalpes
bottom_line: Glide cracks which release into avalanches are still our main concern in Turnagain Pass. These cracks and avalanches are littering the popular slopes in this zone. Look for a "brown frown" on the slope and avoid spending any time underneath if possible. It is unlikely we could trigger an old wind slab on a steep slope.

author: Daniel Krueger
bottom_line: Glide cracks are releasing as avalanches on commonly skied slopes and over skin tracks in Turnagain Pass. This problem can be avoided by choosing not to travel under these "brown" cracks or exposing one person at a time if you must move past them. There is also a small chance of triggering a stubborn wind slab in steep terrain.

author: Wendy Wagner
bottom_line: Glide cracks releasing into avalanches remain the main concern for the Turnagain Pass forecast zone. Continuing to look for and avoid spending any time under these dark cracks is recommended. Otherwise, the snowpack is generally stable and triggering an avalanche is unlikely. The exception would be triggering a small slab in steep rocky terrain.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line: Our main concern remains the continued glide avalanche activity throughout the area. These avalanches are large, destructive, and unpredictable. The only way to manage this problem is to avoid traveling below open glide cracks whenever possible. The passing storm system may bring a trace to an inch of snow to our area, which is not expected to change the avalanche conditions.

author: Wendy Wagner
bottom_line: The main avalanche concern at Turnagain Pass are glide avalanches. This kind of avalanche is completely unpredictable, not triggered by people, and highly destructive. It is important to look for and avoid spending time under glide cracks. Otherwise, watch for old shallow wind slabs that might still be unstable in steep wind loaded terrain.

author: Andrew Schauer
bottom_line: Glide avalanches are the main concern for Turnagain Pass. These are very big avalanches that release spontaneously, so it is important to avoid spending any time under open glide cracks. It is unlikely a person will trigger an avalanche failing within the snowpack, although there may still be isolated pockets of unstable snow in steep, wind loaded terrain.
